children.subject: Ya, I guess the option would be to take Professor El Ghaoui's EE227?
For EE126, a good substitute would be Stats 134/135.
A lot of classes in Berkeley cover Poisson Process and Markov Chain.
We did Poisson point processes and Markov chains in CS 176 in Fall 2013, but I don't know if the topics are the same still (might depend on the professor). Apparently Stat 205B does too.

I don't recall seeing Poisson processes in 176 last fall.

Markov chains are particularly common; within upper-div CS courses, I know 174 and 188 cover them as well.

I should point out that 188 barely teaches Markov models. If you want to actually learn them you should take CS 176/174/etc.

Example: problem #1 on our corresponding 176 homework was to come up with an efficient algorithm for computing the likelihood function of a hidden semi-Markov model (HSMM, generalization of HMM) and then to reduce its running time by assuming a bound on a duration.

I'm not sure I would agree with "barely". The middle third of the course is largely on Markov models, although it's true that it doesn't go into the properties of Markov models / how they work, and instead does more probability/application stuff (e.g. forward algorithm, Viterbi, Bayesian inference in general). That said, CS70 has been covering those properties (e.g. invariant distributions, reducibility) in recent semesters.

But last semester's 176 definitely didn't go that much into Markov models; it treated the topic fairly similarly to 188.

The reason I said 188 "barely" teaches you Markov models was that it teaches you how to use them but barely teaches you how to build them in the first place, which is the real question... after all, it's easy to propose a perfect and efficient model that nobody can build. ;) In fact I don't think 188 even mentions the fact that parameter estimation for an HMM from observations is NP-hard, let alone deriving an algorithm for it.

To exaggerate a bit... it's almost like saying you're learning about cars in a driving class. =P

Sad to hear 176 doesn't cover much of this anymore, but glad to hear 70 is covering more!

Don't they all conflict? It's highly doubtful that they are going to be webcasted (I know for a fact that 126, 127 were not this semester). How are you getting around this? Asking because I was interested in taking those 3 classes too!

history.content: I am interested in optimization and transportation. How is this course workload? Thanks.
history.subject: EE126, EE127, CS294-43?
